description.narrative: Promoting digital rights to access to information in Vietnam Access to information is key to ensure the human rights and civic space in any country. In the new technology era nowadays, promoting digital rights to promote rights on access to information is very important. Currently, the Government of Vietnam is accelerating the Digital Transformation Program 2020-2025, including the 03 pillarsof the e-Government, e-Economy, and e-Society. The Vietnamese government has been committed to improving accountability governance via digital transformation, including facilitation of access to public services, and better interaction between governments and citizens. To ensure the realization of this goal, the Ministry of Information and Communications developed the Digital Transformation Index (DTI), measuring the performances of these 3 pillars. The ICT Index is a metric developed by the Ministry of Information and Communications (MoIC) to measure the e-Government performance. The Index on digital access to information is expected to be a sub-indexin the mentioned ICT index as part of the DTI index. In the National digital transformation program 2021-2025, opening and sharing data, including providing information to citizens is considered an important component, expected to contribute to 30% increase in services for citizens (Ref: IPS source). 2021 is the first year that DTI was published. There are concerns that DTI needs improvements. A research prospecting the monitoring of digital RTI, in reframing RTI that is aligned and desired by GoV would offer a great entry point for the efficient promotion of RTI in practice. In terms of synergies, a number of projects have been conducted to monitor and assess the implementation of right to information (RTI) in Vietnam. Oxfam in Vietnam has conducted annual Rights to Information (RTI) monitoring, and parts of the assessment methodology is available to be applied in this study, i.e. indicators regarding online information disclosure, state feedbacks to citizen information requests online. Monitoring experiences have demonstrated that the assessment on these indicators is a powerful driver of change. Therefore, Oxfam in Vietnam proposes to take this funding opportunity to carry out a study on digital right to access to information focusing on state-citizen interaction, government responsiveness in government portals, open data for socio-economic development. The study will provide inputs and proposed methodology for the development of the Index on online InformationAccess. This Index is expected to be included as a component in the ICT index of the DTI indexof the MoIC. There is a good willingness from the Information Technology of the MoIC in developing this Digital Information Access Index.

participating-org.narrative: In Vietnam , Oxfam is one of the leading international, non -governmental organisation. Since 1955, Oxfam is active in Vietnam withhumanitarian interventions and started development work in the late 1980's. Today, Oxfam works in 26 provinces with people,governments and civil society to promote equality and well-being through social and economic change.
